newsitem.title: USA: FNMA sees earnings gain through innovation.
newsitem.headline: FNMA sees earnings gain through innovation.

text.p: The Federal National Mortgage Association (FNMA or Fannie Mae) plans to reap increased profitability from the ongoing overhaul of some of its operations, the agency's chairman said.

Technology development and a reformed credit-loss management program have helped solidify Fannie Mae's market share and profits, James Johnson, the agency's chairman and chief executive officer told investors and reporters on Tuesday.
Last Thursday, Johnson said in Washington he expected Fannie Mae would post record earnings for 1996 and 1997.
New loss-mitigation strategies have cut the agency's losses on problem loans, Johnson said Tuesday.

"The most successful step involves individually tailored repayment plans, which cost us virtually nothing," Johnson said. About 75 percent of problem loans that are given customized repayment plans avoid foreclosure, he said.
Johnson said foreclosure is the most costly way to resolve a loan that is in default.
"We believe that with our credit-loss management program fully underway ... our credit losses in dollars will be lower in the year 2000 than they will be this year," he said.
Johnson cited technology development as another area of Fannie Mae innovation. Development of mortgage lending and trading software has trimmed costs for mortgage lenders and borrowers, he said.
The agency invested "several hundred million dollars" over the past six years to develop mortgage origination, administration and trading technology, Johnson said.
"We are now in a position to reap concrete benefits from these very substantial investments," Johnson said.

Lenders using such Fannie Mae software as "Desktop Administrator," "Desktop Underwriter" and "Desktop Trader" can, on average, offer a mortgage borrower a reduction of about $800 in origination costs, he said.
Johnson declined to quantify his earlier projection of record earnings in 1996 and 1997.
